thread.title_full: Best ways to avoid online scammers

author: Sophie Elsworth MoneysaverHQ deputy editor
title: Best ways to avoid online scammers
text:
ONE of the best ways to escape an online scam is, if in doubt, do not click.
So far this year Australian consumers have lost $650,000 to online scams and shoppers are being encouraged to take extra care before getting sucked in by money-hungry fraudsters.
COMPARE credit card offers
The Australian Competition and Consumer Authority’s deputy chair Delia Rickard says there are some key ways you can help reduce the changes of being scammed online.
Be wary of fake online shops that might look like the real deal but they ask you to pay in unusual ways.
“If they ask you to pay by money order, wire transfer or load and go cards I would assume it’s a scam under those circumstances,’’ Rickard says.
“Only pay by secure payment methods such as credit cards whereby you have some mechanism for redress if something goes wrong.”
EVERYTHING you need to know about credit cards
Another easy way to identity a dodgy site is by its address. If it doesn’t have “http” in the url and a padlock sign on the site then it’s likely to be a scam.
It is common these days to be bombarded with dodgy emails pretending to offer you some enticing deal or a monetary win such as a gift card or store voucher.
Look for errors in these emails — often they’ll be littered with spelling mistakes and incorrect English that should set alarm bells ringing.
For example if a retailer is offering you a $1000 voucher, question why they would be doing this and if you’re unsure contact the retailer direct to work out whether it’s legitimate.
“If in doubt don’t click on it as it can download malware,” Rickard says. “Call the company direct and find out if it is from them.’’
If you have been scammed it’s not too late to take action.
If you have given away important details to do with your bank account, Medicare information or your driver’s licence contact the relevant authorities immediately.
If you do find you have used your credit card for something that is a scam, contact your financial institution and you may have rights to get your money back.
Rickard urges consumers who want to learn more about scams to visit www.scamwatch.gov.au
